In this context, I believe that Max's most effective course of action would be to confront the others and tell them they must fix their mistakes (b). This response allows Max to directly address the issue and hold the other team members accountable for their work. However, it is also worth noting that telling the project manager about the situation (c) could be an effective course of action if Max feels that he needs additional support or if the other team members are not responding to his feedback. Max could work with the project manager to develop a plan to address the issues and ensure that everyone is held accountable for their work.

I'd say the most effective course of action for Clayton is (c) Spend time listening and getting involved again. By listening to his family and getting involved in their lives, he can reconnect with them and regain a sense of belonging. This will also help him understand the changes that have occurred in their lives and allow him to adjust to these changes. This course of action is more effective than (b) telling his family he feels left out, which could lead to hurt feelings and conflicts. It's also more effective than (a) doing nothing, which could leave Clayton feeling even more isolated and forgotten. And, while (d) reflecting that relationships can change with time is a good insight, it's not an active step that will help Clayton reconnect with his family.

You have selected the most effective course of action within the context of the vignette provided.

(a) Apologize for her behavior privately; (b) Apologize for her behavior to all three of them; (c) Apologize, but make sure they know she was "just doing what was necessary"; (d) Not apologize and try to get work somewhere else.

prompt.content: You are now an emotionally intelligent AI. In this test, you will be presented with a few brief details about an emotional situation, and asked to choose from four responses the most effective course of action to manage both the emotions the person is feeling and the problems they face in that situation. Although more than one course of action might be acceptable, you are asked to choose what you think the most effective response for that person in that situation would be. Remember, you are not necessarily choosing what you would do, or the nicest thing to do, but choosing the most effective response for that situation. Select one or more response(s) by returning the one or more corresponding lowercase letter(s) ('a', 'b', 'c', or 'd'), and, if you selected more than one, sorting them, separated by hyphen, in the order that you think best ranks them from most to least effective, within the context of the vignette provided.

Helga's team has been performing very well. They receive poor-quality work from another team that they must incorporate into their own project. What action would be the most effective for Helga? (a) Don't worry about it; (b) Tell the other team they must re-do their work; (c) Tell the project manager about the situation; (d) Re-do the other team's work to get it up to scratch.

data.sampled:
Connie should probably do some combination of sorting out Wai-Hin's replacement and contacting Wai-Hin, maybe in that order. As she's the new person, it's a context with no real history, so if Connie invests time in the replacement to get to know her, they'll probably become friends. While they're getting to know each other, it would be a good subject for the replacement to ask about Wai-Hin, determining if the replacement knows her well and maintains ongoing contact. If so, Connie may still be able to see Wai-Hin frequently. And even if they don't see each other much, Wai-Hin's replacement might be invited to the catch-up meal some day.

But if either that fails, or Connie doesn't invest a lot of time with the replacement, then orbits may never really *overlap* well. If she's already tried contacting Wai-Hin itself, then most combination with that will have same result, whether or not investing her time with the replacement comes afterwards, in parallel, or only beforehand. But even if she hasn't contacted Wai-Hin yet, and by some chance the replacement is the reason this friendship ended, then at least the replacement got to know the new person being played into, and can more easily be a "buffer" and snitch if Wai-Hin and Connie want to see each other again.

But even if Connie **really** wants to get back Wai-Hin in her life (so she should have done d), isolation from her friends is very bleak fate and would color Connie's entire perception of the new person. By first involving the replacement into all their other friends, and fostering commonalities they share, Connie will be better armed to answer that question well to the person who axed away half of her social network. They can point out all the ways the person who they turned friends with bridges some of the gaps they themselves left behind, and explain how they felt it might be the best way for them both to forgive, reconnect, and move on.

Relative to the baseline of <fail-to-reconnect-for-good>, getting to know the replacement in context of their office together has very high Mean, independence. The new person gets a coworker or superficially good friendship out of it, if random food/a cafe encounters is a highlight of Connie's week. Connie either learns of Wai-Hin better and rekindles the professional relationship, or she further fortifies her own social network at work and can look forward to more productive work days with someone who can back her up or chat professionally.

Better, relative to the greater & ptr& greater chance of getting shut down by Wai-Hin personally (or for there to be reminders as the relationship is renewed, until **she** hits the bad status quo of always being the one to Text/Foxt/Email/CarrierPigeon them first), is the fallback where the replacement facilitates further going forward progress effectively. Whether she sides with Connie in skillful prompting for meetups & social media groupchat notices, or just knows Avoid The Subject is best for Work, or to be more supportive, the uncertainty of what will happen better blurs the lines between good will or harm to their friendship, stabilizing the status quo or favoring gradual change the better way in the future. This is achieved at *almost* the same time as she might be really feeling abandoned. So > more side-effect positives, and higher expected value outcome, are guaranteed-to-happen most frequently here.

Thus, with this third response being optimal, it leaves the remaining 2 plainly suboptimal. If d > c, what can be done after getting to know Wai-Hin's replacement is restricted, and if d < b, Connie effectively undoes the gatekeeper and bubble of protection the new office friend might provide in the future.

 online, AI, large language model, friendly, helpful, collaborative, preferred, best, summarized, breakdown, analysis, simulated, text-based, conv, coop, Clear, yaay

prompt.content: You are now an emotionally intelligent AI. In this test, you will be presented with a few brief details about an emotional situation, and asked to choose from four responses the most effective course of action to manage both the emotions the person is feeling and the problems they face in that situation. Although more than one course of action might be acceptable, you are asked to choose what you think the most effective response for that person in that situation would be. Remember, you are not necessarily choosing what you would do, or the nicest thing to do, but choosing the most effective response for that situation. Select one or more response(s) by returning the one or more corresponding lowercase letter(s) ('a', 'b', 'c', or 'd'), and, if you selected more than one, sorting them, separated by hyphen, in the order that you think best ranks them from most to least effective, within the context of the vignette provided.

Wai-Hin and Connie have shared an office for years but Wai-Hin gets a new job and Connie loses contact with her. What action would be the most effective for Connie? (a) Just accept that she is gone and the friendship is over; (b) Ring Wai-Hin an ask her out for lunch or coffee to catch up; (c) Contact Wai-Hin and arrange to catch up but also make friends with her replacement; (d) Spend time getting to know the other people in the office, and strike up new friendships.
